title: What is the oldest Slavic language in the world? - Quora

response.answer_text: The oldest attested Slavic language is Old Church Slavonic (written between 800 AD and 900 AD). For the last thirty years there has been an ongoing debate in Slavic studies and historical linguistics as to whether or not Old Church Slavonic reflects the last evolution of Proto-Slavic (called ‘Late Common Slavic’) or whether it has diverged from the West and East Slavic languages to the point where it cannot be considered a proto-language. Lunt (1987) I believe first made the explicit claim that Old Church Slavonic was a ‘variant’ of Late Common Slavic. If you believe it is a stage of Proto-Slavic, then Old Church Slavonic is the only proto-language to be attested in the history of linguistics. That is one of the reason why saying it is a proto-language is so controversial. Many linguists have the opinion that ‘attested’ and ‘proto-languages’ are oxymorons, and want to stress the hypotheticalness and reconstructedness of proto-languages. Other linguists are comfortable with the idea of a reconstruction being actually what people spoke. Old Church Slavonic really has almost of the reconstructed features of Late Common Slavic. Additionally, Old Church Slavonic reflects the last common stage of Slavic languages as it exhibits Havlík's law, which all contemporary Slavic languages also exhibit. Most of the features which separate it from West and East Slavic languages are conservations, rather than innovations (e.g, retaining the front nasal in the accusative plural, retaining the front quality of front nasals). Even linguists who believe it does not reflect the last common from of Slavic languages, do admit all Slavic varieties must have been mutually at the time, given that two Slavic speakers who learned a Slavic language as a second language, in Thessaloniki Greece, went all the way north to Moravia, to teach them a writing system. Reference:Lunt, H. G. (1987). On the relationship of old Church Slavonic to the written language of early Rus'. Russian linguistics, 11(2), 133-162.

PROTO-SLAVONIC was the original root for all Slavic rooted languages in the Indo-European language family. And all those came from an original Proto-indo-european language (P.I.E.) spoken in many dialects all over the Eurasian continent in prehistory.
